channel.title: Decoding rscd passwords on db?
channel.description: Ok well I've tried a few things, but nothing is working, I know its probably something simple but I can not figure it out, can anyone tell me what I need or what I need to do to decode them?

item.title: Decoding rscd passwords on db?
item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

Ugh, this entire post is made with the intention of getting other peoples passwords. What kind of a dipshit are you? The passwords are encoded for a reason.

Read full topic

item.title: Decoding rscd passwords on db?
item.dc:creator: @mapu mapu
item.description:
@mapu wrote:

[quote=“marwolf, post:1, topic:257049”]Excellent post, Mapu. That answers if the passwords are encoded along with the usernames or not. The passwords are only md5 encrypted and there is nothing else added, unlike in the username’s case.

8800 GTS is getting 180M hashes per second. For an 11 character alpha numeric password, even with 100000000000 combinations attempted, it could not bruteforce my password. It only came up with 8 tested characters before it gave up. It did not even test symbols.[/quote]

There is an Admin on the mirc channel I think her name is Legion. Send her all of your hash’s in 1 file and she will crack 95% of them. I sent her the entire released rscd database from Reines and she cracked nearly all of them.

Read full topic

item.title: Decoding rscd passwords on db?
item.dc:creator: @mapu mapu
item.description:
@mapu wrote:

It’s encrypted with md5 hash keys.

Very very easy to crack them.

G data is a browser based tool Gdata or an irc which has a far more advanced database in which you can also submit hash’s and the md5 bot decrypts for you.

/server irc.rizon.no

#rainbowcrack

Btw this is probably the best info you could get

Read full topic

item.title: Decoding rscd passwords on db?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

^ I believe your talking about Peter, as it definitely was not be.

As for this topic, trying to decode the hashes in the sql, the only way you can do that is by using an md5 bruteforcer (which could take you a lot of time without GPU acceleration)

If you have a server, you can just log the passwords they enter before it gets hashed (when they are trying to log in)

Read full topic
